title: 105_hr3312
content: The "Federal Aviation Research and Evaluation Act" (FARE Act) establishes the "Federal Aviation Research and Evaluation Board" (Commission) to carry out specific duties. The "Federal Aviation Research and Evaluation Act" establishes the "Federal Aviation Research and Evaluation Board" (Commission) with duties including reviewing complaints of predatory practices by air carriers, studying airfare marketing and pricing practices, and submitting interim reports to Congress with findings and recommendations for legislation or administrative actions. The Commission, composed of 7 members from various sectors, will be appointed by the President, Senate Pro Tempore, and Speaker of the House within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled by the Commission. The Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed by various officials, will continue its duties even if there are vacancies. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. A quorum requires five members present. The Commission, with 7 members appointed by officials, operates with a quorum of five members. A member can vote by proxy but not count towards quorum. The Chairperson is elected at the initial meeting, held within 60 days of the last member's appointment. Subsequent meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority of members. The Commission has the authority to appoint staff, including experts and consultants, and may also request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. Staff appointments are not bound by certain civil service laws. The Commission has the power to appoint staff, including experts and consultants, and may request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in its duties. Staff appointments are not bound by certain civil service laws. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from government agencies. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and use the United States mails. Administrative support services can be requested upon need. The Commission, upon request, can receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. It also has the power to issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence related to investigations, with the ability to enforce compliance through a United States district court order. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services and issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence related to investigations. The United States district court can order a person to appear before the Commission and failure to comply may result in civil contempt. Subpoenas are served in the same manner as those issued by a United States district court under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for services needed to carry out its duties, without being bound by certain statutes. It also enjoys immunity as an agency of the United States under title 18, United States Code. The Commission will terminate 3 years after its initial meeting. It is considered a "Federal agency" for the purposes of certain federal tort claims provisions. $4,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2002 to carry out the Act.
